message: Today we welcomed a new Congress, and with it, a new opportunity to effect change, grow our economy, and create a more perfect Union.   The next few years will bring serious challenges. But I'm hopeful they will also bring serious progress.   Thank you to Senator Mikulski for her decades of service and fierce advocacy on behalf of Marylanders. Senator Van Hollen and I won't let you down.  Let's get to work.

Republicans' plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act is dangerous. 4.3 million Americans - our own neighbors and family members - will immediately lose their health insurance. More than 30 million Americans will lose their insurance over the following few years.   What's more, repealing the ACA  will take us back to a time when insurance companies could discriminate against people with preexisting health conditions. That simply isn't right. All Americans deserve affordable coverage.

421,000 Marylanders have health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, when they had none before. Republicans are planning to repeal the ACA without any plan to cover them.   Those are 421,000 Maryland families who will suddenly lose the ability to see a doctor or fill life-saving prescriptions.   Repealing the ACA without a comprehensive, clear plan in place is dangerous. It's wrong.   The Affordable Care Act covers tens of millions of Americans nationwide.   Again: tens of millions.   It's made it illegal to discriminate against people with preexisting health conditions. It's ensured being a woman is not considered a "preexisting condition" wherein they must pay more for the same coverage. It has expanded Medicare coverage for senior citizens.   It also needs tweaks. No one denies it can and should be improved. But a repeal? Without any plan for what happens when millions go uninsured overnight?   Unconscionable.

Today the Chesapeake Bay Foundation released its new "State of the Bay" report - the first since 2014. The Chesapeake Bay's health is now rated at a C-.   That's an improvement over the D+ it was given two years ago, and proof that efforts to restore the Bay work. This modest achievement was hard-won by the grueling work of countless public servants, Maryland's incredibly committed environmental community, and our farmers, whose cooperation has been essential.   I'm so grateful to all. But there is a lot of hard work left to be done. We cannot give up or grow complacent to how desperately the Bay needs help and restoration.   The seafood industry in Maryland contributes $433 million in income and 8,332 jobs to the local economy every year. Behind those numbers are fathers hoping to save for retirement, mothers hoping to save for their children's education, and children who owe the roofs over their heads to the Chesapeake. We owe them better than a C-.   Let's keep working. Volunteering. Advocating. Our economy and future generations will thank us for it.

Happening now: I'm introducing a bipartisan bill to impose comprehensive sanctions on Russia. Every U.S. intelligence agency has concluded they purposefully interfered with our presidential election.  That's an attack on our democracy. That's an attack on our sovereignty. We must respond appropriately and decisively. This is about protecting our country - not our politics.  To that end, I'm very proud to have my Republican colleagues Senators McCain, Graham, Rubio, Portman and Sasse supporting this legislation.

This week Republicans voted to start the process of repealing the Affordable Care Act -- without any replacement plan in place. Without even letting the American people see a replacement plan of any kind.   If they are successful, more than 400,000 Maryland families who have insurance under the ACA will suddenly lose the ability to see a doctor or fill life-saving prescriptions.   That is morally indefensible. Republicans: you've had more than 7 years to map out your plan. Where is it?   If you have solutions to improve the ACA, I welcome them. If you have a clear plan for my 400,000 Marylanders and the tens of millions of other Americans, let's see it.   Otherwise, repealing the ACA is unconscionable.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has calculated that if the Affordable Care Act is repealed according to Republicans' plans, 18 million Americans will lose their health insurance within the year.   Let that number sink in. 18 million. 18 million families suddenly unable to see a doctor or fill life-saving prescriptions. That's unconscionable.   Meanwhile, premiums will skyrocket for everyone. The CBO now calculates premiums would rise 20 to 25 percent in the first year after repeal. They would double by 2026.  Republicans will have to answer for those figures if they continue down this path of repealing the ACA without any immediate replacement plan.  The ACA covers millions of people. It makes discriminating against pre-existing conditions illegal. It allows students to stay on their parents' plan through age 26. It expands Medicare and Medicaid for our elderly and disadvantaged.   It requires improvements. Not a repeal. Especially not without a plan.

After careful consideration of her qualifications and the responses she offered at her hearing, I've decided I must oppose Betsy DeVos for Secretary of Education.  I cannot support an Education nominee who has expressed plans to put Americans' tax dollars toward private and charter schools, while our public schools are in need of those resources. And our public schools must be our priority. It would be especially wrong to support a nominee who wants to funnel money from public schools to charter schools while our nation's public school teachers are regularly investing their own money from their own pockets in our students, in an attempt to bridge funding gaps.  Further, at her hearing, Ms. DeVos would not commit to enforcing federal safeguards for students with disabilities. I was shocked and deeply troubled by her equivocation on such a basic and commonsense issue. She also committed no plans for improving college affordability - a growing concern for Maryland families struggling under ballooning tuition rates and student loans.  I believe Ms. DeVos is sincere in her beliefs and in her desire to serve her country, however for these reasons, I cannot and will not support her nomination.

This year, 26 million working families and individuals will claim the Earned Income Tax Credit. In some cases, their EITC tax refund will comprise as much as 30% of their annual income. As a result, EITC serves to great reduce poverty. Last year, these working family tax credits lifted an estimated 9.4 million people out of poverty - 5 million of them being children.  These results have made EITC the single highest-impact savings program for low-wage workers. We must protect it. And every Marylander should ask their tax preparer whether they qualify. #EITCAwarenessDay http://bit.ly/2iRR8gy

Right now our nation's healthcare laws are being heavily debated. But this year, we're all still protected by the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). You won't be discriminated against for preexisting conditions. Your children under 26 can be covered by your plan. Birth control is free or affordable. And the majority of participants get financial help paying for their plan thanks to the ACA.   That all applies to Maryland's health exchange, but open enrollment ends TUESDAY.   So take a look now - see if you qualify for subsidies. Ask your family members and friends to take a look. It only takes a couple minutes to browse plans, get a cost estimate, see what help you're eligible for.   You can go to MarylandHealthConnection.Gov or call them and get one-on-one assistance: 1-855-642-8572.   They're open 8 AM to 4 PM today and tomorrow, 8 AM to 6 PM Monday, and 8 AM to 10 PM Tuesday - the last day to sign up.

I'll be here. Join me if you can.   Make no mistake: last week's executive orders were designed to target Muslims. Including Muslims who have already been vetted and granted visas and Green Cards, including Muslims from nations who are critical allies in our fight against terrorism, including Muslim students already studying here at our schools. There is no religious test in this country. We must fight to keep it that way.  The ban against refugees is also appalling. It's a moral affront and patently unAmerican. These are families fleeing violence and persecution. To whom does "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddles masses yearning to breathe free" apply if not to them?   These actions make us less safe; they give terrorist cells the fuel they need to demonize the United States and radicalize more into their fold. No ban. No wall.

One issue on which there is bipartisan agreement is that Russia is an adversary, not a friend, of the United States. Vladimir Putin has illegally taken land from other countries, he has helped the Assad regime in Syria commit war crimes against civilians, and he has made a habit of jailing or killing anyone who opposes him.   The sanctions we have in place against Russia are therefore critical. They are our best, most concrete response to Putin's illegal and aggressive behavior.  That's why this week -- alongside Republican Senators Lindsey Graham, John McCain, and Marco Rubio -- I introduced the Russia Sanctions Review Act of 2017, which would necessitate congressional approval before sanctions are lifted or relieved.  This bill would put an important check on the President's power to ease sanctions on Putin.   I'm grateful so many of my Senate colleagues -- both Democrat and Republican -- agree that we must hold Russia accountable for its crimes, and that ensuring sanctions stay in place is absolutely key to that mission.

I've just introduced S.411, a bill banning racial, religious and discriminatory profiling by law enforcement. On the heels of executive orders that deliberately target Muslim immigrants and refugees, passing federal anti-profiling legislation feels as great a need as ever.  Let's be clear: profiling based on race or religion doesn't make us safer. It distracts law enforcement from actual threats, and it foments mistrust between law enforcement and the very communities that they protect and serve. It foments mistrust between law enforcement and the very communities that could be helping them to identify criminals.  What's more, discriminatory profiling is unAmerican. No one in this country should be arrested, detained or banned from entering based purely on the way they look or pray. We are better than that. And we don't need it to stay secure.
NA

Friends,  I'm proud to announce I'll be participating in a Town Hall this coming Sunday, alongside Senator Van Hollen and Congressman Raskin.  The Town Hall will start at 6:30 PM in Silver Spring, with ample time set aside for a Q&A session with all of you. We'll be covering a lot of ground and addressing many of your growing concerns. If you can make it, I hope to see you there:  Silver Spring Civic Center 1 Veterans Place Silver Spring, MD 20910  Sunday, February 26th at 6:30 PM  NOTE: This is a ticketed event, however tickets are free and 90 are still available for the outdoor area. We will be speaking both indoors and outdoors. You can go here to register for yours: sen.gov/VN05

Marylanders,  If you were unable to get a ticket, or simply can't make the trip to Silver Spring, tonight's Town Hall will be streamed live here: http://tpmobilization.org/?p=483  Looking forward to the chance to meet many of you and address your concerns.   See you tonight, Ben

Today's news about Attorney General Jeff Sessions raises more questions than answers. Why did Russia want to meet with him during the campaign? Mr. Sessions was, at the time, a surrogate - by his own admission.   Why didn't he disclose his meeting with Russian officials when he was directly asked during his hearing - and was under oath?   Why hasn't he clarified his remarks?  These are serious questions. They deserve a serious, nonpartisan, independent response.   That's why we need an independent commission to investigate. Every one of our intelligence agencies has said Russia attempted to interfere with or influence our presidential election. Our intelligence community isn't partisan. They're concerned with the integrity and security of both our country and its right to self-determine our own leaders. We must be too.

Today is International Women's Day, and I'm proud to be celebrating it. Women's rights are human rights. And we need to acknowledge and support that creed with more than just words. It's time to pass the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) - a short, straightforward and commonsense amendment to the Constitution that would finally guarantee full, nationwide equality of the sexes.   I've been a leading proponent of the ERA for years, and was proud to reintroduce it in Congress just two months ago. I'm committed to seeing it through. Full equal rights for women deserve more than lip service.   Today millions around the globe are celebrating International Women's Day by asking - and showing us - what a day without women would be like. Good for them. They're telling us their work and contributions can't be taken for granted.   If you can't imagine a day - or a country - without women, then fight with them. Fight alongside them. For affordable healthcare, for reproductive rights, for equal pay for equal work, for paid family leave, for ending violence against women.   Let's make sure these issues, and others, receive the attention they deserve every day of the year.

After extensive consideration of Mr. David Friedman's record, I've concluded I cannot support his nomination as America's top diplomat to Israel.   Since the creation of the State of Israel, support for the U.S. relationship has been bipartisan, bicameral, and supported by successive U.S. administrations. I believe it is critical for the U.S. ambassador to Israel to be seen as a unifying figure in this enduring relationship.   Mr. Friedman's past record would make it very difficult for him to serve as that unifying force.   I appreciate Mr. Friedman's efforts at his nomination hearing to express regret for his record of divisive, inflammatory, and offensive statements.  Unfortunately, I believe that the body of Mr. Friedman's published work will still compromise his effectiveness in representing the United States to Israel.   Furthermore, taken together, Mr. Friedman's statements and affiliations make it clear that he does not believe a two-state solution is necessary for a just and lasting peace. That deeply troubles me, and it also undermines his ability to be a credible facilitator for the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.   For these reasons, I must vote against his confirmation.

Friends, be safe throughout the winter storm tonight. Forecasts are still varying, but every model suggests central and western Maryland will get hit especially hard with snowfall.    So make sure you're prepared: if you haven't already, stock up on any medications you might need to last a couple days, and check that your flashlights have batteries. If you can, fill up your gas tank now - full tanks help prevent frozen gas lines. Keep warm clothes and blankets on hand in the event of a power outage.   The National Weather Service is a good place to watch for changes and developments as the storm progresses. I'll be watching with you: http://www.weather.gov/

President Trump's budget cannot be taken seriously.   In Maryland, a healthy economy depends on a healthy Chesapeake Bay. And neither are up for negotiation. Congress must quickly reject this budget before the absurdity of the President's proposed cuts — including outright elimination of the EPA's Chesapeake Bay Program — causes ripples of uncertainty and fear across the entire Chesapeake Bay watershed economy.   President Trump has said his focus is on strengthening jobs and the economy. If that's true, he can help us protect our oysters and crabs and seafood industry. He can help our tourism industry prosper with clean rivers and creeks. He can care about our farmers and ensuring they have healthy, fruitful land.   Until then, he can rethink his budget.

FBI Director James Comey has confirmed the FBI is actively investigating Russia's interference in the 2016 election, as well as any potential connection between Russia and the Donald Trump campaign.   This revelation confirms it: we need an independent, nonpartisan, transparent and public investigation. Senators Feinstein, Leahy and myself pushed for one back in December - I'm still pushing for one now.   This concerns all Americans, of all political affiliations. The integrity of our elections must be sacrosanct. It benefits no one, from either party, if we tacitly accept other countries' attempts to undermine our democracy.   We must be bipartisan in our refusal to be swayed by foreign powers.   A comprehensive and transparent investigation into 2016 is the first, most important step toward that refusal.

Friends, this is big.   Nevada just ratified the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA), putting us just two states shy of amending the U.S. Constitution.   It's time.   It's time for Congress to extend the deadline for ratification so that this can become law. It's time for two more states to step up and MAKE this law.   And it's time for us to have a national dialogue about why we need the ERA so that our states feel compelled. The ERA is shorter than two tweets, but it would clearly and fully guarantee equal rights and protection to all our nation's women.   #INeedERA because I want to know that every branch of government - both federal and local - is Constitutionally obligated to fully protect and respect women's rights.   Why do you need the ERA?   http://www.kolotv.com/content/news/Nevada-ratifies-Equal-Rights-Amendment-416854473.html

Today marks 7 years since President Obama signed the Affordable Care Act (ACA) into law. Since then, it has covered more than 20 million Americans who previously had no health insurance, no way to see a doctor, no means of obtaining prescriptions.   More than 300,000 of them are Marylanders.   Of course, the ACA still needs work. And we have good ideas to improve it. But none of them are in Republicans' Trumpcare bill.  This new bill - which even some conservatives have said is horrendous - is a con. Plain and simple. It's being sold from folks who promised to look out for the middle class, but who are peddling healthcare legislation that would cut the middle class' subsidies and allow companies to charge more for preexisting conditions. They can't deny you coverage, but they can charge you more.   Lastly: the objective and nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office - which has been used by both parties to analyze legislation for decades - recently reported this bill would cause 24 million Americans to lose their insurance altogether.   24 million. Those are real people. Some of them would be your own neighbors, coworkers, family.   Republicans had 7 years to come up with an alternative to the ACA. Is this really the best they've got?

I listened closely to Judge Gorsuch's testimony last week. And I've read through many of his rulings and public statements.  Combined, I found an extensive legal record that is peppered with examples of putting corporate interests before working Americans, showing hostility to agency decisions that protect our environment, disregard for women's health, marginalizing students with disabilities, and many more troubling decisions.   Further, despite his protestations, Judge Gorsuch's record points to a jurist who has not separated his political views from his legal views. I also do not believe that he would serve as an independent check on this president, who has tested the limits of the Constitution and the separation of powers in a way that no other modern president has done.   Judge Merrick Garland, who was never even given a hearing, was considered by almost all independent judicial scholars to be mainstream. Judge Gorsuch does not enjoy a similar evaluation.  For these reasons, I must vote against his nomination to the Supreme Court.

"America first," or America for sale? That's the question before us all as President Trump prepares to host Chinese President Xi Jinping at his private club in Florida this week.   Trump has made a number of abrupt policy changes toward China lately. In February, he suddenly switched his stance on the key issue of Taiwan’s status — in favor of China’s preferred policy.  When asked about the switch, White House spokesman Sean Spicer said that when Trump negotiates, "the president always gets something."  The problem is that while it is clear China got something, the administration has refused to tell us what the United States got in return.   The American people deserve to know whether President Trump's and his children's many lucrative businesses are the beneficiaries.  The American people have a right to know whether the president's decision-making is being conducted in their public interest or in his private financial interest.   And that's why he MUST divest his business interests. Immediately. The Founders included the #EmolumentsClause in our Constitution to protect against conflicts of interest exactly like these.

Friends, I want to be clear why I'm supporting the filibuster of President Trump's nominee to the Supreme Court:  I have examined Judge Gorsuch's record. I've listened closely to his testimony. And everything I've learned about him clearly indicates that he holds deeply conservative, extreme political opinions that he's unable to separate from his judicial opinions. His past rulings have restricted or eliminated rights for the disabled, for workers, for women, for countless Americans.   Further, after the unprecedented obstruction of Judge Merrick Garland - recall that Republicans refused to even meet with him or hold a hearing - I would have expected GOP leaders to consult with their colleagues on this nomination, to ensure a comparably mainstream candidate was chosen.   They did not. They blocked Judge Garland for a record 10 months, then blocked input from Democrats or Independents on who will ultimately fill the vacancy.   For these reasons and more, I'm supporting the filibuster - which exists to force compromise. I hold out hope that Republicans will hear our filibuster and compromise, as was intended.   But if they choose to simply bend Senate rules to eliminate the filibuster instead, that choice is theirs and theirs alone. It will be a historic mistake, one which they will have to own.

This week marked two years since the death of Freddie Gray.  Two years later, and we have not yet managed to fully restore trust between our police and our communities. And we must do so, if we are to have the type of Baltimore we want, and the city that we know Baltimore can be.   The ongoing criminal justice reforms provided through the Consent Decree, and the complementary efforts made by the Baltimore Police Department, are fundamental to continued progress. But we must see them as the beginning of progress, not the conclusion of it.   We must continue to make gains in our efforts to restore communities by improving housing and schools, and by increasing access to green space, healthy food options and quality, affordable healthcare. We must continue to work to ensure that local residents have good jobs and job training programs, expansive and effective public transportation options, and comprehensive social services available to all Baltimoreans who need them, including returning citizens.   We must continue working to ensure that everyone's human and civil rights are respected and protected. We must keep finding ways to be better friends, neighbors and community members.  In the near future, I will be introducing newly expanded legislation that contains many of the critical reforms included in my End Racial and Religious Profiling Act and BALTIMORE Act, both of which are designed to reinforce all Americans' civil liberties and promote best practices in policing.   The steps forward that would be enabled by this legislation remain vitally necessary both in Baltimore and nationwide, and I look forward to working closely with the citizens and leaders of my home town to make them possible.

President Trump's tax reform "plan" isn't a plan at all. It's a few bullet points, and all they do is spell out how Trump continues to put wealthy businesses before middle class families.   What's more, it would blow up the national deficit like never before. And remember when he ran his campaign as a deficit hawk? I do.  Two months from now, when this "plan" can't pass muster, President Trump will suddenly realize tax reform is complicated.

The President questioning why the Civil War occurred, and suggesting Andrew Jackson may have been able to prevent it, is bizarre and troubling.  But his questionable musings cannot derail us from our actual work. And today I'm pleased to announce we have a budget deal that protects the EPA - including critical Chesapeake Bay cleanup funding - the National Institute of Health, and Planned Parenthood. This is all a far cry from President Trump's budget proposal. And I'm glad.
NA

"Alarming" is an understatement.   Bromances with the world's dictators should not be - MUST not become - U.S. foreign policy.   This trend is dangerous, irresponsible, and cripples the United States' credibility.   As does failing to articulate what our foreign policy even is.   President Trump must begin expressing a clear foreign policy agenda - ideally one that doesn't include praise or applause for despots and human rights violators.

Today FBI Director James Comey testified before the Senate. He was questioned on the FBI's investigation into the Trump campaign's potential collusion with Russia. Director Comey could not say much, but confirmed the investigation is extensive and ongoing.   It made me wonder:  Remember back when Republicans said that being under FBI investigation was a disqualifier for being President?   I remember.

President Trump has implied he may back out of the Paris Agreement - a critical, hard-fought international agreement designed to fight climate change. Such a move would be beyond irresponsible. It would be dangerous for our economy, for our ecosystems, and for our relationships with allies.   We cannot be casual about our international commitments.

Thank you to all our educators, especially Maryland Public School teachers. You impact countless children's lives for the better. We owe you so much more than a single day of recognition, but taking the time to express gratitude is always a good start.

Candidate Trump led chants of "lock her up" based on Director Comey's egregious actions during last year's campaign.   It is incredulous that President Trump would now use that as an excuse to fire the FBI director.   This latest action has now added more questions upon questions. If there was ever a doubt that we need an independent commission with outside investigators to work full time on behalf of the American people to figure out who did what, when, and why, all of those doubts are now gone.  The American people are entitled to answers.

We stand nothing to lose by appointing a special prosecutor and establishing an independent commission on Russia/Trump. Nothing to lose by merely seeking the facts - whatever they might be.   But we stand much to lose if we do nothing. If we assume we already know the facts, or worse, that we don't need to know them.   Democracies flourish when truth is viewed as a virtue, not an enemy.

Today, I want to pause just one moment. Because it's important to recognize that, through all this country's challenges, our public service professionals continue to work tirelessly on our behalf every single day.   Maryland is home to more than 136,000 federal civilian employees and countless more public service pros. It's one of my greatest honors to represent so many people who work in service of their country and their communities.   Whether it's Maryland's educators pouring their hearts into our children, our police and first responders protecting our neighborhoods, or our government employees improving and providing essential services - our public service workforce is what makes us exceptional.   Thank you all.

If President Trump wants to engage with Russia, he should start by engaging on human rights.  Just days before Secretary of State Rex Tillerson flew to Moscow, accounts surfaced of secret prison camps in Russian-controlled Chechnya, reportedly ordered opened by Chechen President Ramzan Kadyrov, where gay men have been systematically detained and tortured.   This pogrom against the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community - and the broader crackdown throughout Russia on opposition, human rights, pro-democracy and anti-corruption activists in advance of Russia's 2018 presidential election - demands a vocal U.S. government response.   It's past time for real foreign policy leadership, Mr. President.

Releasing highly classified information to one of our greatest adversaries is outrageous and unacceptable.   In doing so, President Trump has potentially compromised our partnership with a country that is giving us critically important intelligence information. His actions could make it more difficult for us to get this kind of information in the future, thereby jeopardizing the national security of our country and the safety of the American people.    When will the President realize that Russia is not our friend, or our partner?   They are a bully and an adversary that seeks to undermine our country - and democracies elsewhere in the world - at every point. Mr. Trump consistently fails to see the ongoing threat from Moscow and each time he does, the situation becomes more dangerous for our country.

Today the FCC voted to begin rolling back net neutrality protections. If they continue down this path, they'll create an internet wherein broadband companies get to choose different speeds for different websites.   That's unacceptable.   If broadband companies are granted power to control our access to websites, they can control access to information, to businesses, to news - or whatever else - in their own favor.   That's why net neutrality is so critical to freedom of expression, equal access to the web, and, importantly, the ability of small business to compete online with big ones.   Rolling back net neutrality helps no one but large broadband corporations. Period.   I'll continue to support net neutrality in every way I can, but we're in this together. If you agree the internet MUST stay open and free, tell the FCC. Leave a comment on their docket, and make it impossible for them to ignore our voices: https://www.fcc.gov/ecfs/search/filings?proceedings_name=17-108&sort=date_disseminated,DESC
First pitch at @Orioles #CelebrateMaryland day w @ChrisVanHollen.

Such senseless, profound loss. My deepest condolences go out to the family and friends of Richard Collins III, along with all of Bowie State University.  By all accounts, Second Lieutenant Collins had distinguished himself academically and would have done the same in his forthcoming military service. The senselessness of this loss is deeply disturbing, as are reports that the perpetrator may have been motivated by racism. I welcome the federal role in this investigation and stand with Bowie State as justice is sought for this heinous crime.

A budget is supposed to reflect a president's priorities and the values this country holds most dear.   President Trump's proposed budget for 2018 just reflects how cruelly out of touch he is.   It slashes billions of dollars in critical #healthcare spending, not to mention billions more from Medicaid, public education, homeowner programs, and much, much more.  Yet it has no problem wasting money on a new border wall that simply will not make us any safer, or any freer.   This budget proposal should be considered dead on arrival. Fortunately, our founders developed a system of checks and balances to help ensure that it is. I intend to do everything within my power, including working with reasonable Republicans, to fight this outlandish budget and enact a far more realistic one that actually contributes to our economic growth and prosperity.

The Congressional Budget Office's official analysis of TrumpCare was released yesterday. In a word: devastating. They assess that if the GOP's plan becomes law, 23 million people will lose their healthcare.   23. Million.  The ACA isn't perfect. I'm willing to work on it, with Democrats and Republicans alike, to make improvements.  But this? How is this an improvement to anything?

Soon, President Trump is expected to announce whether he'll keep the United States part of the Paris Climate Agreement.  I am imploring him to do what is best for the health of the American people; what is best for our economy and our relationships with our economic allies; and what is, quite simply, right.   I am imploring him to stay.   Climate change is undeniable. The Paris Climate Agreement represents our best hope for combating it and mitigating the utterly disastrous effects it will have on our economy and our public health.   But if that isn't compelling enough, there is the simple matter of our country's credibility. This is an international agreement. We cannot abandon it at will without risk of devastating our relationships with close friends and allies.   Leaving the Paris Accords now would be a shocking abdication of American leadership and American credibility. Not to mention a material threat to our planet and the millions of jobs that depend on natural resources.  This is an opportunity to step up to the plate. This is an opportunity for Mr. Trump to be the reasonable, responsible president he claimed he wanted to be after the election. If he fails in this, he will fail generations of Americans to come, and I will fight the ramifications of such an irresponsible decision with every tool at my disposal.

Baffling.  That's how I'd describe President Trump's decision to withdrawal the United States from the Paris Climate Agreement.  President Trump likes to talk a lot about jobs. And for good reason: families across the country are experiencing a lot of economic anxiety, and it's our job as elected officials to address that.  But 1 in every 50 new jobs is a clean energy job. It is one of the fastest-growing industries in the United States, and the single-fastest growing energy field.   So when we talk about jobs, let's be sure we're being honest about them. The Paris Climate Agreement was about many things, but principally, let's not forget it was about our economy. It solidified our relationships with close economic partners; it promised to spur innovation and energy freedom here in the U.S.; it was poised to create tens of thousands of new, well-paying jobs across our country.   Abandoning the Paris Agreement is of the most shockingly irresponsible policy moves in recent memory. For our environment, for our diplomatic relations, for our credibility as a nation, and yes, for our economy.   The world must be exasperated and disappointed in our country today. Moreover, the American people must be exasperated. Because of today's decision, China, Russia, India and other countries will move quickly to assume our spot at the head of the climate diplomacy table, harming our energy job prospects.  I am exploring legislative solutions to mitigate the damage done today and ensure the U.S. remains a climate change leader.

I'm proud to #WearOrange in honor of National Gun Violence Prevention Day, and most of all, in loving support of all the victims of this senseless and tragic epidemic.   Every single day, more than 90 Americans are killed by guns. And I know we can't prevent every tragedy. But with better enforcement practices and common sense reforms like mandatory background checks, we CAN save lives.   I will not stop fighting on this issue until we do.

Today, former FBI Director James Comey shared with us details of his interactions with President Trump.  Those details were disturbing. I trust Special Counsel Mueller is looking more deeply into these interactions and their intent to derail a legitimate FBI investigation.   Still, today's testimony makes clear: it is time for Republican leadership in Congress to acknowledge publicly how dangerous the president's actions have been to American rule of law – the very foundation of our nation. It's time for them to step up.  It's also time for an independent commission. Special Counsel Mueller will investigate criminal activity, but only an independent, 9/11-style commission will review ALL facts related to Russia's interference and make recommendations for fighting and preventing their interference in the future.   That's why I introduced S. 27, a bill that would establish such a commission.   For my colleagues in Congress who have yet to cosponsor S. 27: I hope you were paying attention today.   I hope you've been paying attention these past months, when every single U.S. intelligence agency has conclusively said Russia interfered in our election - and I hope you heed Mr. Comey's warning.   This is not about Republicans or Democrats. Russia is coming after America - our values, our principles, our democratic system of government.

Friends,  Right now, under President Trump's direction, the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is considering permits that would allow oil companies to use air gun arrays along the East Coast to probe for oil and gas.   NOAA is accepting comments on this policy change right now.  The oil companies seeking these permits require NOAA's approval because this kind of seismic activity is known to disturb marine life. What's more, this seismic probing would span the whole Eastern seaboard from Florida to Delaware – including the waters that border and feed into our own Chesapeake Bay.  This represents the first step toward opening Atlantic Coast federal waters to offshore drilling. It also represents a grave threat to our coast, our environment, and the countless families whose lives and livelihoods rely on a healthy Bay.   Let's be clear: this first step toward drilling off our coast has nothing to do with a greater need for oil. America is already the largest producer of oil and natural gas in the world. Further, oil companies already have 24 million acres of offshore public land at their disposal.   Instead, this move toward Atlantic coast drilling puts every community along the Chesapeake Bay at risk. Seismic probing for oil threatens to disturb critical wildlife, and with it, the livelihoods of farmers and fishermen, along with all those working in the tourism and seafood industries. Remember: the Deepwater Horizon disaster utterly decimated more than 1,100 miles of coastline and did so without respect for federal versus state boundaries. The risk for another incident of this nature simply outweighs any small, potential benefits.   These past few months, the single-most common question I have received is, "What can I do? How can I help?"  If you agree that seismic probing for oil off Maryland's coast is dangerous and unnecessary, the answer is simple: leave a comment with NOAA. The top, right-hand corner of my Tracking the Trump Administration page will show you how: https://www.cardin.senate.gov/tracking-the-trump-administration   You have 30 days to make your voice heard and influence the outcome of this fight. Meanwhile, I'll continue to oppose this with every tool at my disposal.

The president is gambling with millions of Americans' access to safe, clean drinking water.  The president is wrong to put so many families' health in jeopardy like this. The move is blatantly partisan and can best be described as shortsighted and dangerous. Repealing the Clean Water Rule is yet another example of President Trump adding uncertainty to our economy and our communities nationwide.  Everyone needs water: old and young, rich and poor, Democrat and Republican. This should not be - and until recently, has not been - a partisan issue. Water is not political. It is a basic, fundamental right and necessity.   And the Clean Water Act has protected our drinking water - as well as our wetlands - for 45 years. And by every measure, it has been an unequivocal success.   Despite all of this, President Trump is gutting its key Rule and handing yet another partisan gift to big corporate polluters.   We need more protection for our water, not less. Despite President Trump's and Administrator Pruitt's attacks, I will continue to fight with every tool at my disposal for America's right to clean water.

I'm proud to announce I'm joining a bipartisan group of Senate colleagues to move forward legislation that would reauthorize key programs at the heart of restoring and maintaining the Chesapeake Bay.   Among other critical programs, the HELP for Wildlife Act would reauthorize the EPA's Chesapeake Bay Program until 2023.   A healthy Bay means a healthy economy for Maryland and the entire Chesapeake Bay Watershed region -- which cannot be accomplished without a reliable federal partner. States rely on the EPA's Chesapeake Bay Program to provide federal accountability, enforceability, and resources to restore the health of this national treasure. Combined with reauthorization of the Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Initiative, the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, and protection for our fish and birds, this bipartisan bill is a significant victory for the Bay.   The bottom line: less pollution means more oysters and crabs, healthier farmland, more boats and tourism on the water, and more jobs.

Now, they have announced they're moving on to a repeal and run strategy -- repealing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) without any plan to replace it. And it would force young people under 26 off their parents' plans, adding yet another burden onto our nation's college-aged students and their families.   We cannot entertain this. It won't be easier for the 32 million Americans who will lose their health coverage because he and Congressional Republicans are hell bent on killing a program that truly was working until they decided to throw a wrench into the system. It won't be easier for the 19 million Americans who will lose their Medicaid coverage. It won't be easier for the millions of Americans who struggle with mental health issues or opioid addiction who will be cut off from treatment options. I filed legislation recently that builds on the current system, provides more stability in the individual insurance marketplace, brings down the cost of premiums, and overall health care costs (link below). I urge my colleagues to take the time to listen to these proposals to improve and strengthen our current health coverage system.   Repealing the Affordable Care Act is not going to happen. Let's move forward together and get things back on track.

The latest threat to the Chesapeake Bay does not come from greater pollution, dead-zones or a natural disaster, but from President Donald Trump and his White House. That much was made clear when President Trump released his 2018 budget, which proposed completely zeroing out funding for initiatives like the Chesapeake Bay Program.  A new package of bills, called the Hunting Heritage and Environmental Legacy Preservation (HELP) for Wildlife Act, provides bipartisan pushback against these attempts to marginalize critical Bay programs by putting some muscle behind established federal partnerships.  Among its provisions, the HELP for Wildlife Act pumps up the EPA’s Chesapeake Bay Program with a five-year reauthorization at $90 million per year — more than the program has ever been funded.   In total, the legislation authorizes more than $100 million annually to restore and protect the Chesapeake Bay, in part through reauthorizing two other programs with dedicated funding for the Bay: The Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Network and the Chesapeake Bay Gateways Grants Assistance Program.  In a year in which it has been challenging to get pro-environment bills moving, I am pleased that there is such strong bipartisan support for Marylanders and the Chesapeake Bay. I am pleased to be cosponsoring this important bill.

Today, on the 45th anniversary of the Clean Water Act, let's remember: water is not political. Every community, every family, both needs and deserves clean, safe water.  For 45 years, the Clean Water Act has protected our drinking water, our wetlands that filters pollutants, our communities from floods, and provided habitat for wildlife in Maryland and throughout the nation. The Clean Water Act has been an unequivocal success.  Prior to the passage of the Clean Water Act in 1972, the United States was in a state of crisis similar to what the world’s developing countries face today. The Chesapeake Bay was deemed to have one of the world’s first marine dead zones, high levels of PCBs were being discovered in the San Francisco Bay, and unfettered industrial pollution had rendered a majority of waters across the U.S. and unsafe for fishing and swimming. The immense scope of the tragedies in our nation’s waters was too great for Congress to ignore.  In 1972, Congress took decisive action to address this growing threat, and that response brought about the Clean Water Act.  Why was the Clean Water Act so essential? Clean water upstream means clean water downstream. Streams and wetlands filter pollution, reduce flooding, and give fish and wildlife a place to live—and provide our nation’s great hunting and fishing areas. Farmers depend on clean water for irrigation, crops and livestock. Tourism, hunting and fishing, manufacturing, the construction industry, the food and beverage industry, the healthcare industry, the oil and gas and nuclear industries, the textiles industry, and the logging industry—all are highly dependent on clean water. The Clean Water Act also provides for critical habitat for endangered species: one third of all endangered species live only in wetlands.  The Clean Water Act provides a framework for the state and federal partnership to clean up the Chesapeake Bay. Our investment in the watershed region is paying off—Maryland’s portion of the Bay was dead-zone free in early July.   We need more protection for our water not less. President Trump’s recent repeal of the Clean Water Rule puts that in serious jeopardy. The move is blatantly partisan and can best be described as a shortsighted and dangerous gift to polluters. Despite President Trump’s attacks, I will continue to fight for America’s right to clean water.

Marylanders are bearing the costly burden of President Trump's sabotage of the individual market.  After months of injecting uncertainty into the markets with threats to end cost-sharing reduction (CSR) payments, President Trump finally announced this month that he will indefinitely halt the payments. These payments are not a bailout for insurers, but are subsidies to help lower out-of-pocket expenses.  Insurers in Maryland responded to President Trump's decision by refiling their 2018 premium rates to account for the unpaid subsidies.  As a result, the Maryland Insurance Administration just approved a rate increase of 58.2 percent for CareFirst HMO Silver plans and a rate increase of 76 percent for CareFirst PPO Silver plans. Kaiser Permanente was granted a 43.4 percent increase for its HMO Silver plans.   In sum: CSR payments offset $100 million of costs for 2018, which will now be passed on to consumers.
